pros: Once upon a time, I worked with some AMAZING people that LOVED working with students. They have all left OU.

Things will never change because OU doesn't want change. -Diversity is just a buzzword at OU. -I'm not sure why professional development is stilla thing becasue management doesn't care what you've learned that could potentially retain students, create a safe work enviornment, or make things more productive. -Most of managment hate their home lives and would rather work 24-7 and expect you to do the same. They don't care that you have a family or a life outside of campus. -Parking -People with no knowledge regarding supporting students make the decisions about how we support (or DON'T support) our students. -No opportunity for growth and leadership doesn't care about your growth. -If you want to learn about something, try doing on your own because you won't get the support. -No one is on the same page. -If you're more knowledgeable or more educated that your superiors, are you treated horribly.

pros: The OU Econ department has many talented and driven professors, specializing in an array of subfields in economics. The younger professors (think associate, and assistant professors) are typically more flexible, encouraging, optimistic, and hopeful, likely because they haven't had years of stress from the academic system.
cons: Work can sometimes be hard to find, but reaching out to professors to see if they need research assistants is always a good place to start. Often, the jobs are offered for part-time during school year and full-time during the summer. Try to keep an open mind and understand that research isn't going to be available 24/7. Also, pay may be less than your classmates who are interning at large companies, but the quality of life for research assistants is much, much better.

pros: My professor is doing well in my field.

review_title: It depends on where you work.
pros: I've worked in four different areas for OU at this point. The expectations, community, scheduling, and compensation differ depending on where you work. My favorite thing as a student employee is that I have always had a lot of input in my scheduled work times.
cons: Again, it depends on where you work, but not all wages are fair in my opinion. In three of my four jobs (research assistant, office assistant, and peer tutor), I've made about $10 an hour, up to $12.50 for SI and $15 (I think) for Math Corps. Some of these I think are fair for the workload, but not all.

review_title: Phenomenal experience, this job set me up for my career and next step
job_title: Career Ambassador in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: Great team, high energy, learning workplace and professional competencies, constant mentoring and learning experiences, cross department projects, networking, interview skills, campus outreach, this job left me feeling rewarded each day knowing I helped people take that next step. Very much like how the internship helped me to take my next step.
cons: Not many, for the most part, sometimes other departments would take a little longer to reply or coordinate but that is with any workplace. Our work would turn ed out quickly, efficiently and with high quality.

review_title: Great job with great retirement match, but lower salary, poor health benefits, and inadequate travel support.
pros:
Some really great people work here. 

The retirement salary match of 16% for faculty is excellent. 

The 3/2 teaching load for faculty in my program is reasonable. 

Expectations for service and research are reasonable. 

Tenure is attainable for faculty who do the work. Very few people turned down for tenure in tenure-track positions.
cons:
The administration cut health benefits significantly, going from excellent coverage to an “outcomes based” discriminatory program that is not 100% covered. Some workers face higher copays and deductibles as a result. 

The salaries are low compared to peer institutions, as was revealed in recent market-based increases. 

The amount of money provided per year for travel support is woefully inadequate (about 1,000). The administration should recognize the importance of travel for faculty research and increase this support significantly.

pros:
Great University. Lots of experience to gain. There are many Good professors. Some of mt professional classes provided unique experiences that I would not likely have had else where. The facilities are in good condition overall. Many buildings and areas are in the process of being renovated. OAKLAND University is a top-rated academic institution offering students a personal, high-quality, affordable education. With 114 bachelor degrees, and 72 graduate and certificate programs available, students find what they are looking for to succeed.  OU offers scholarships, grants, loans and work-study programs to help students pay for their education. Our Financial Aid office also is available to help.

Located in suburban Rochester, Mich., in north Oakland County, OU boasts one of the most picturesque campuses in the country.  And, there is always something to do - from watching Division I sporting events and joining student organizations to biking, golfing and jogging.
cons: Its a smaller university. Difficult classes.

job_title: Ingénieur/Chef De Projet En Bureau D'études in Rochester, MI
pros: Decent living wages and benefits
cons:
Management in various departments are dysfunctional and unqualified. The old adage of,           "To many chiefs, and not enough Indians" is apropos.  

Administration is extremely disproportionate compared with its support staff which is grossly inadequate to handle the volume of students, programs, and services the university wishes to offer, and to perform them with well thought-out processes with adequately staffing.

review_title: A platform to get a new job
job_title: Student Worker in Rochester Hills, MI
pros: The best thing about the job was that they would work around your school schedule. It doesn't matter when your classes are, you're able to work around that. It's a great little platform to get some on the job experience and help land you another job after graduation. Also, my boss was great.
cons: It's so political. So much so that no matter what you do, it'll be rejected by higher ups. Unless you're a full timer you'll feel insignificant to the university. As a student, it felt like my time at the university was just 'busy work' I wasn't able to really dive into projects like I had hoped.

job_title: Full Time Adjunct Professor in Rochester, MI
pros:
Benefits
Instructional and material support
Accredited programs
cons:
Hostile Work Environment in SON
Hierarchy/Pecking order.  PhD's are arrogant without substance and hostile toward of adjunct faculty
Tenured faculty do not exhibit good work ethics and many need to resign-been there too long
Students threaten faculty with appeals when they receive the grade they deserve instead of higher grades they demand
Unions support upper management and tenured faculty instead of due paying adjunct faculty
Adjunct Faculty must travel to off site campuses, most quite a distance, with no mileage reimbursement
Lack of diversity

review_title: Average university, static, not moving forward quick enough
pros: Metro area presents opportunities, growing school, not-too-demanding-students, decent travel funding, some research opportunities available
cons: Political culture, senior admin/faculty not open to change/ways of doing things. While a small daily irritation, the lack of parking for faculty/staff is indicative of lack of respect for employees/faculty.  More networking-social events would be beneficial for newer employees.  The academic weaknesses in the student body make instruction challenging at times.  A greater recruitment effort for other parts of the state/country might help, as would increased residential opportunities both directly on campus and in the surrounding area.

pros: Very flexible schedule - you have to be there for class, but "office hours" can be any time or really anywhere you want
cons: Not much direction from the more senior professors.  As a part-time professor, I don't have much freedom to change the class around, but the mentors are not very responsive to new ideas.

job_title: Professional Employment Coordinator in Rochester, MI
pros: Oakland University is a solid university to work for.  Opportunities abound around the university, upward movement is possibility depending on educational background.
cons: To move up, it is much easier when you have connections (like most places) or know people around campus.  Pay is typical for university, if not on the low side.

review_title: Dead-end, low pay, no goals or objectives
pros: Good retirement contribution at 14%, good vacation which accumulates a lot after 6 months of service. Work life balance is achievable.
cons: Experience is 100% dependent on your supervisor, so if you get a bad one you are SOL. You need their permission to do anything, including company-wide rolled out options such as working one day a week remote (prior to COVID), or even to engage in professional development opportunities. So if they don't like you, you have no recourse. There is no moving up or career path, and decisions occur in a vacuum. HR and level 2 up from your position are completely disengaged from personnel.  It's a place to become a complacent robot and do what you're told or you're out, in which they have an entire year to assess and hang over you due to the mandatory one year probation. The most employees can dream to do is either leave, make a lateral move, or even take a demotion in order to escape a toxic group or environment, which I hear past Buyers in my Department have done. The office politics are worse than a company. Your fate is entirely dependent on having a conforming, no questions asked personality. Merit counts not whatsoever, as there are no goals or objectives, core competencies, or any kind of performance measure.  The pay is abysmal, far below industry standard, even for Universities. Horrible experience, no compassion, very unprofessional people.

pros: OU gives a good opportunity to do your own research that other, bigger universities lack, especially at an undergraduate level. This allows you to get more experience, especially doing something that is your own work instead of being stuck being an assistant to someone for years.
cons: Though OU being a smaller university can be good in some ways, on the other hand, there aren't as many labs to choose from and isn't as much instrumentation available compared to bigger schools.

review_title: Oakland University is a great place to work.
pros: Everyone at Oakland University is very friendly. The benefits are great. I have never had a bad experience working there.
cons: The positions are union so if you work harder than other employees you will still receive the same pay. Some people take advantage of that. I had nothing bad to say about any of the people running the university.

pros: I'm currently working as a Research Assistant and really love it.  The Professor I'm working for is very appreciative!
cons: The lady I submit my time sheet to is extremely abrasive and talks down to me.  She's clearly a miserable person.  OU will lose great employees because of her abrasiveness.

pros: Able to learn from professors and work with them to make sure I  know what is important in a job and what is not
cons: I do not like the pay scale very much but being a student still and learning the skills needed when I graduate, the learning far outweighs the pay

cons: The pay was not the best but all things considered it was more for the experience, practice and helping others who are in need.

pros: After working here for a little while, everyone becomes one big family on campus. Hours also fit around any class schedule.

review_title: Don't be fooled by smiling faces...disabled need not apply

review_title: Enjoyed working with college level students

pros: Oakland really works with your student schedule.  They are also understanding of stress.  They care about you succeeding and having a good experience.
